subject: Re: Sweep Tuning of AM Radio Band
author: kenneth b thomas
full_text:
right on, dave,

and i know what you mean, the desired voice seems to persist across 
several station hops.

i took the front off the radios and removed string and just grabbed 
the flywheel if plastic or bolted a non-conductive disc on it. the 
size of the flywheel seems about right for a slow enough sweep and 
you can hear voices stretching off each station when it works.  i 
never recorded or understood anything-just noted "otherworldly 
feeling" or spooky resonance of sounds.  right now i have a car radio 
with a toothpick jammed into sweep lever. 

--really interested in software now, though, alas.

if the spread spectrum is maxed in computer bios it has something of 
the same effect.

kthomas
illinois

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, " RetroCom" <vfp19968@...> wrote:
>
> 
> I have a very sensitive old AM tuner with a flywheel tuning system. 
I tried several recording sessions manually sweeping the tuner 
through the AM band late at night. I got pretty good at keeping the 
dial moving at a constant rate of speed. This is not nearly as good 
as Frank's 'hands off' random tuning method but it still produced 
some results. What impressed me most is that some of the voices sound 
the same, even though I tuned through several channels. This attached 
capture could be a technical message.
> "Plug a million hertz"   One Million Hertz = 1mhz = 1000khz, which 
is close the center frequency for the AM broadcast band.
> Dave
